pros: Great people to work with. Everything is a new challenge, which I like.
cons: Contact Centre/hotline can do better. Sometimes the information given by the officers on the hotlines contradicts on what we, the digital ambassador were told at branch. For example, the branches’ banking hours: 11am to 7pm(until 31 March 2023, new hours with effect of first of april) but we at the branch will close the issuance of queue tickets 1-3 hours earlier depending on the crowd of the day. But…The hotline does not know this and relay the branches are still issuing Q Numbers until 7pm so customers assuming what they told were right would come down and say that the hotline say we are still issuing the Q Numbers until 7pm when we already stop the issuance. This causes a lot of problems when we, The Digital Ambassadors have to reject the customer and tell them to come back another day when the branch is still crowded after the stopping of q tickets. We are the ones that will be complained by the customers.

review_title: Local Bank Culture is not for me
pros: • 2 restaurants which are nice (but I haven’t eaten there personally) • Marmalade Pantry café at the 6th floor • Recreation club with cheap classes • If you are Graduate Talent, you can get promoted to AVP5 in 3 years. • Free drinks in the pantry for some departments.
cons: • Going on courses organized by the company is passively discouraged (by not replying you) especially during probation, bc most likely your colleagues don’t go and spoil the market. • Some people managers will badmouth you and tell their team not to interact with you. • Some bosses are passive aggressive, they will not tell you upfront but hope you get the hint, such as wanting to share cab fare with you, quiet firing, hint for you to resign, vague feedback that you are not a fit. • If you have previous working experience, your boss will have high expectations of you, you must be able to immediately hit the ground running, almost immediately work at the same level as experienced staff, be proactive about issues that may crop up even though you are new, you cannot just wait for work to be assigned. You should also update your boss daily on what you are doing bc they don’t trust that you are working. • No proper training or handover. Just very messy in general with no proper tracking. • High turnover, 1 way is to see on Linkedin which jobs only receive very few applications like 10+) • The JD is very fluffy but what you actually do is very manual. All the teams have cheem names and big words. • Long meetings which take more than 2 hours and start at 6.30pm. Occasionally you will have to skip lunch to do work. • Very strict place, you have to wear formal, no short skirts, don’t take coffee breaks, don’t be a few minutes late, don’t bring people from other floors to tour your floor. If you are used to that, then it will be ok for you. • Mostly have to work in office bc face time is important. • Flex dollars is kind of low, about $300 for me.

review_title: Perhaps not the best place for long term careers.
pros:
1. Reasonably good benefits.
2. Good bonuses, provided you stay till bonus payout.
3. People at ground level are in general, nice to work with.
4. Overall a good place for a short term stint, provided you can negotiate a good compensation package.
cons:
1. Lack of clear direction/decisions from senior management, resulting in a lot of second guessing by middle management which in turn results in challenges in interpreting and fulfilling expectations by the ground level employees.
2. Unrealistic, and at times bordering on delusional, expectations by senior management, in terms of tech delivery timelines and funding 
3. Excessive micromanagement by senior management in Tech deliveries
4. Has a culture of finger pointing and passing the buck, instead of taking accountability, when things go wrong
5. Following Tech Processes are a matter of convenience, until someone high enough up, says otherwise, in which case its ok to ignore processes.
6. Directives from senior management in Tech are frequently more focussed on short term benefits instead of long term, sustainable gains
7. Employee performance evaluations based on presentation / packaging, as opposed to content in terms of actual employee performance with tangible outcomes / improvements
8. Lack of growth and recognition for existing Tech employees, resulting in very high employee attrition, with minimal to zero efforts being expended by the organization to retain employees.
9. Middle management in Tech needs to work on soft skills, providing better leadership and balancing workload distribution to ensure employee efficiency and well being
10. Expect minimal to zero monthly salary hikes in yearly appraisal

review_title: Read this before you decided to take the offer...
pros: if you are the new joiner and there are few of new joiners also, you are safe. otherwise, goodluck with all of the nonesense problems in workplace
cons: Gosh there are so many things I need to say here bcs THERE IS TOO MUCH! 1. The management as a whole is really SCREWED. yes, when I say screwed is bcs we always did not get clear outcome from one person to another. they will tell you to ask other dept and that other dept will throw u to the other next dept. and so on... until yoh get scolded for not getting the clear answer. 2. Lack of direction. repeating stuff. they will only remember when you do things wrong and bad. but when u do well, nobody will remember it and they ignore as if it never happened. 3. Toxic workplace to start with. those back end staff will never teach you the proper way, they will scold you instead until they are happy. When you do things wrong, they will ask you to ask our seniors when our seniors are engaged. like should you be the one to be our mentor bcs this is technically what you are in charge for? not to mention the gossips behind you, they will gossip you until there is no link related to them jst bcs they want to make everyone hate you. validation seeking is very much on point here. basically is a company politics that every workplace would have. (I wont mention their names here, but i will remember these people as my motivation to go up from what yall have been doing for me all these time). 4. you have to get click with your manager and colleague, even if u hate it. if not, goodluck. it will be hard for you to seek for every little things for help. also, lucky if you get a good manager to work with, otherwise, just leave. 5. if you do well, you feel like you are the boss. if you are not, they will treat you like a garbage. but ofcoz those who performed well will still have to endure the scold and argue with the staff before you are well known for having good sales performance. 6. again this is demoralizing yourself. 7. you have to be people pleaser (maybe bcs of doing sales but what i mean by people pleaser is rlly next level). you have no choice but to go work during your off day, OT everday to call and assist customer demand. not to mention the paperwork given, you might be staying until 9pm everyday in which this is out from your contract agreement. 8. i have seen my peers who worked longer than me are struggling with mental health issue due to this, and the way they treat the financial consultant staff are really very awful. felt very pitu to them when they jst want to work to earn their living. 9. statistic have shown that ocbc have many high turnover rate. so i dun have to explain another long essay for this. again, im not trying to scare people off, this job, if you able to do well, go ahead. is good when you can ace this job well and you are numb enough with all of the scold from the supervisor. otherwise, dont waste time on this.

review_title: One of the worst Job!!!  Coming from someone who join from MNC !!Join at your own risk
pros:
1.)Better benefits than most MNC. Have insurance cover for your family
2.) Colleagues are friendly and easy to mingle
3.)BM are approachable and helpful in order for you to achieve your target
cons:
1.) Training is provided but almost non existent. What you learn in your training campus cannot be use when you deploy to the branch. That means you have to pick and learn the job fast when you are deploy after training.

2.) Everything is about getting results and number. You will be force to sell certain endowment plan that they want you to sell. If you sell something that is not what they want you to sell you will be fault for it. This is despite of understanding from customer perspective.

3.) They will cut your commission if you dont sell certain products. You work so hard without life to hit the target to qualify for the commission than end up they cut some because you cant sell some products that is require.

4.) Glorified insurance agent. The focus is not on understanding the customer but just pushing on endowment plan to hit the number they want. If you quit and you have no other work experience than good luck in searching for new job. Your experience is now no different from a failed insurance agent.

5.) No work life balance at all. Your weekend you could be with your family and friends but end up you will be in branch. Public holiday you will be at roadshow. Roadshow canvassing customer to buy the plan

6.) Micromanaging. You will expect to do cold calling every night.If you are a new joiner and cannot hit their expectation. Be prepare to on your camera and microphone to call infront of your equal failed colleague with those manager looking on. There is no lesson from them on how to do cold call better. They think by watching you call the number of closure will increase. Totally treat you like a kindergarten kids who need constantly watch over.

7.) Every month your target will restart from 0. You have to start over again keep finding new customer and push the product they want you to sell again and again. There will be never ending to do this until you choose to resign. Even you are promoted is just change of products only.

review_title: Old school bank trying to reinvent the wheel
pros: Pays well, has systems for everything, traditional and safe.
cons:
Old School vs New School on a daily basis. 

The VPs cannot agree on direction, and administration is more concerned on face-saving rather than progress. 

Everything, and I mean everything boils down to sales, even if the product needs improvement. A perpetual loop of mediocrity where products are rushed out for sales and hence it has poor sales, which requires new product innovation. 

Fellow colleagues have little drive for actual excellence, mainly focused only on bonuses by meeting old school KPIs.

review_title: Pros and Cons working at a Contact Centre
pros: - A perfect role to gain vast amount of bank product knowledge. If you want to experience the high level of stress, productivity and expectation of your efficiency as an employee, this is the perfect stepping stone to test yourself.
cons:
- Vast majority do not commit more than 1-3years in this role. You do not gain any particular useful skillset in this role, which may hinder your chances to find job elsewhere. The high turnover rate results in the workplace to be filled with inexperienced service staffs, which only adds on pressure on the senior colleagues to hit the departmental targets.
- Progression in this role is extremely slow.
- Long working hours.

job_title: Assistant Manager, Customer Service in Singapore
pros:
The great thing about this workplace is, they are constantly hiring people. Even if you have no experience working in a financial institution or background in finance, you can also be given the opportunity to become a customer service executive given your aptitude and qualifications. 
 
Training is provided to ease you into the role and the staff are supportive.
cons: It is common to see people leave the organisation. Anyone is replaceable. KPIs and productivity are very important. The organisation does not value the customer service business unit, which is more like a liability, as much as other business units which brings in the bacon.

pros: High basic (incl allowances) for a pretty entry-level job.
cons: Colleagues are snakes, senior staff choose walk-in queues so junior staff don’t get to even press on good oppty queues at all (just do service for customer, can’t even do your walk-in sales) so juniors really have to stay after work till 9 everyday to do TC while the seniors just happily go off after branch closes since they already have their walk-in sales. Also, have to work weekends. You won’t see your family much. Your BM can also be extremely micro-managing. Customers are mad, sending in complaints that contain lies about you just because they are mad that they can’t get their problem resolved at their definition of quickest time possible (everything takes time and the staff here are already doing their best), and the management sides with the customer, EVEN when you can prove otherwise. Kind of demoralising isn’t it. Commission is also really low right now. Is there even a point to tolerate all the crap from customers when you don’t even earn much 😂

pros:
1)	Stable job and good absolute pay. Management is compassionate enough to retain those who are lagging in performance.
2)	Colleagues can become friends. These include people who would weather the storm as a team.
3)	Compensation and benefits are competitive if there is time to make claims.
4)	Mr Tsien is a very personable CEO with an eye for business growth. He works harder and longer hours than many others.
cons:
1)	Organizational restructuring plans dished out with no clear focus communicated to employees. 
2)	Suggestion to middle management to pull their socks up. Knee jerk reactions to customer and user issues usually result in after office hours investigations and team discussions circling around with minimal progression. More focus should be placed on long term sustainability plans but this has been neglected due to day-to-day fire-fighting and limited resources.
3)	Heavy reliance on a few key employees has resulted in an imbalance of workload.
4)	Employees’ mental wellbeing taking a hit. Long hours (minimum 12 hours a day plus some weekends) are causing a toll on some employees and their families. There should be focus to improve the organizational culture after attempts to investigate and pinpoint to individual troubled employees.
5)	Department that is supposed to be at the forefront of technology has problem even obtaining basic working resources - laptop speed could be improved and delays in getting replacements when laptop has reached end of life. Hot desking concept implemented for a department for which people are expected to work quite frequently from office due to security and information access. Pen must be self-funded if needed.

review_title: Great benefits but no work life balance and with political senior management
pros:
Benefits such as marriage leave is good. Company believes in training and development and has a wide selection of courses to attend. 

Colleagues are great and the initiative to care for the environment is spearheaded by a group of passionate individuals. 

If not for the culture and management, this would have been at least a 4 star review.
cons:
This is specific to the CFS division. Extremely long working hours. Having ONE family day in the entire year doesn’t equate to work life balance. 

Don’t hire enough headcount and staff are overworked. This is added by the unnecessary top down direction to launch certain products/services asap when it doesn’t necessarily meet the consumers’ need.

Always rushing to market with the flag pole mentality to be first in market but products/services developed is to the management’s liking or driven by P&L.

The processes and amount of red tape here is shockingly insane that it affects productivity.

review_title: I hope everyone reads this before joining
pros: The salary and benefits are average. A good retirement ground (OCBC does not fire employees) - which leads to many people doing their minimal trying to past each day and things move very slowly.
cons:
1. This place is a top-down dictatorship and at the end of the day, the person at the top decides it all.

2. The top person puts numbers in front of its employees - Which explains the high turnover in the department (average of 5 to 6 staff tenders in the period of 6 to 8 months as an executive role, multiply that by 2 to 4 times for sales staff) Every employee is seen as a number not human. You’re expected to sell your life to the company and work even after 12 am into the weekends and even on your leave. What’s the point of giving you so many benefits when you don’t have the life to use it?

3. No foresight (Root of all evil) The management here has no foresight and constantly wants to be first in everything, which is good but what’s the point if you don’t maintain your first-mover advantage and launch a product which is flawed? Agile means launching a product with it’s essential/critical features are ready and not launching a broken product and fixing it AFTER it is launched. That is why there is so much firefighting over here and it is honestly a vicious cycle. You’re just firefighting because of the flawed process/product you have designed/launch initially which made the workload heavier instead of lessening the burden. (Then you blame your people for not hitting the KPI). As much as the acquisition is important, do allocate some money for your retention team and don't expect solutions to be free - What's the point of having a good striker if your goalkeeper allows the other team to keep scoring? 

4. Listen to your experts – SCRUM Team is a team formed by specialists who are seasoned in their respective fields. You don’t design an entire system without input from any specialist but just a product manager just because you “Like/Trust” the PM and think that what you designed is what the customer wants with different officers calling you every day. Honestly, if I were a customer and you called me every single day just to ask me to accept your loan offer, I would go to a competitor bank with a more efficient service, better rates, and less irritating and seamless process. (Feels like I’m being nagged at by different teachers for the same homework every day) 

5. Honestly, this is one of the companies that still practice discriminatory hiring – E.g Why does a First-Class Honours Graduate and 2nd Upper get paid differently when other banks have already scrapped this practice? (FYI, Diversity is not included in its core values) 

Overall, I cannot express how disappointed I am with this company. When you work here, it just feels like everything is way behind time
